title: What is the history of magnetism and mesmerism, including Mesmer's role and legacy?
first_phrase: This text discusses the history of magnetism and its influence on people. The author explains how the idea of magnetism dates back to classical times with Galenus, Varron, Apollonius, and then in the Middle Ages with Arab authors and books on magic and alchemy. During the Renaissance, thinkers like Pomponatius, Bacon, and Paracelsus began to speak of the influence exercised by one person on another and used the word "fascination." The text continues by discussing famous practitioners of magnetism such as Greatrakes and Gassner, who predated Mesmer's "animal magnetism" doctrine. In the last 200 tokens, the author describes Mesmer's arrival in Paris and how his ideas appealed to the public's fascination with emotion.
content: Pomponatius, Bacon, Paracelsus parlent de l’influence exercée par un homme sur un autre, et se servent déjà du mot fascination. Van Helmont, en 1630, appelle même magnétisme l’influence occulte exercée par les corps entre eux à distance, et atteste que l’homme peut envoyer au loin la force de sa volonté. En 1673. Maxwell publie un traité de Médecine magnétique, pendant que Greatrakes devient célèbre pour les guérisons de maladies incurables au moyen du seul contact. Vers 1760, un prêtre suédois, Gassner, exerçait le même genre de thérapeutique, de sorte que quand, en 1774,survint Mesmer, suédois aussi, mais médecin, avec sa doctrine du « magnétisme animal », celle-ci avait été déjà préparée par une longue série d’empiriques, de thaumaturges et de charlatans. Mesmer eut le mérite, ou la ruse, de deviner le moment psychologique de son temps et do se rendre pour opérer dans une ville avide de toute émotion comme Paris.
last_phrase: In conclusion, the history of mesmerism and magnetic healing dates back several centuries, with notable figures such as Paracelsus and Bacon exploring the concept of one person's influence over another. The rise of Mesmer and his animal magnetism in the 18th century marked a turning point in the study of magnetism, with debates raging on the efficacy of the practice. Despite being dismissed by scientific societies, the fervent followers of the mesmerism movement continued to innovate, as demonstrated by the discovery of artificial somnambulism by de Puységur.
